title: ushering in a new dawn for
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFor the pioneering four-piece group from Skye, Gaelic is central to what they do – but don’t call them standard bearers for the language. They prefer instead to view Gaelic as a natural medium for their music # a not atypical outlook for their island generation raised with the language as part of their education during the s.And this should be encouraging, for the key to the future survival of the language will lie not in its exceptionalism, but in its ordinariness.While Gaelic may be natural to Niteworks, what sets them apart is how they use it. Their trademark sound is forged from the rich Hebridean song tradition of their native communities, and the dance music they listened to in their bedrooms, and later in Glasgow nightclubs.They have just released their third album # A’ Ghrian,– which follows the eponymous debut album of  and Air Fàir An Làwhich came out in .In what should have been one of the marquee events of Glasgow’s Celtic Connections festival, last Friday Niteworks should have been on stage with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra. But to immense frustration and disappointment, Covid restrictions were not been lted in time and the concert has been rescheduled for the summer.Unsurprisingly, lockdown and the pandemic are themes that have influenced the new album, says band member Allan MacDonald.. “It has been over two years since I have been to a club as a punter.“That was a huge part of our lives. I wouldn’t say it has changed our musical tastes, but what we listen to at home now is dferent to what we would listen to in a club.“That has influenced us and the direction we are going as a band. We’re also getting a bit older, there’s two in the band that have young families now and this album is perhaps a bit more reflective than the others.”It is approaching  years since the quartet put on their first gig – at Braes Hall as part of the year of Highland culture celebrations in . Their first EP followed in , and Niteworks have since become regulars on the festival circuit # including annual appearances at SkyeLive in Portree.They aren’t full time as a band, however, and online rehearsing was a familiar process to them long before the outset of the pandemic.Allan, who is from Braes and from a family of pipers, works in renewable energy and is based in London. Synth and keyboard player Innes Strachan from Breakish works in sound production in Glasgow drummer Ruaraidh Graham, also from Breakish, works in Edinburgh for Historic Environment Scotland and bass player Chris Nicolson, from Braes, is with the BBC in Inverness.One of their ‘lockdown projects’ included writing the music to mark Edinburgh’s Hogmanay, and in turn this led to the orchestral collaboration and the more ‘expansive and cinematic’ sound of the new album, says Ruairidh Graham.“We were partly inspired by our work writing the music for Edinburgh’s Hogmanay Fare Well film that reflected on what  had been like for many during the pandemic,” he adds. “The nature of the project required broad expansive sounds, and that led to us going further in that direction through the writing and recording of the album.“Our upcoming orchestral concert for Celtic Connections further reinforced our desire to keep down that path.”There is an abundance of vocal talent to be found on A’ Ghrian, including from long-time collaborators Sian . Celebrated Scottish singers Kathleen MacInnes, Beth Malcolm, Hannah Rarity and Alasdair Whyte also feature, and Niteworks have incorporated English folk and Scots songs into their repertoire for the first time.The album, which was funded by Creative Scotland and recorded in autumn , also features Fiona MacAskill, Aileen Reid and Laura Wilkie of Kinnaris Quintet alongside Susan Appelbe on strings.A’ Ghrian is available to buy on CD and stream and download on all digital s, and the band will tour the until the end of . A documentary on the band is also due to be aired on BBC Alba soon.

title: tobar an dualchais brides day the birthday of
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine or ‘the dead month’.   or Saint Bride’s Day. This falls in with ‘Candlemas’ on nd February as a Christian festival and a traditional end of the Christmas season. Candlemas commemorates the presentation of the infant Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem as described in St Luke’s Gospel and when some denominations bring candles to their church. Candlemas is also one of the so-called ‘Quarter-days’ marking the changing seasons of winter, spring, summer and autumn. It is followed by Whitsun, Lammas Day and Martinmas as the term-days with their administrative and legal implications for the payment of rents and flittings. Saint Bride or Saint Bridget has been one of the most popular of the saints of the celtic church. Of course, there were many ‘Bridgets’, but the one whose festival date is on st February was ‘Bridget of Kildare’ in Leinster whose death was dated to AD . Bridget was one of the patron saints of Ireland and is remembered in the tradition of plaiting rush crosses around st February to set over doors and windows to protect the home from fire and other danger.   or the endearing ‘Bride’s little fosterling’.’ . ‘Bride’s Day, the birthday of spring’. century, traditions of Saint Bride were collected by Alexander Carmichael among his prayers, hymns, blessings and charms from the Hebrides. He suggests that accounts of Saint Bride were not easily recovered and summarised the tradition: ‘The serpent is supposed to emerge from its hollow among the hills on St Bride’s Day, and a propitiatory hymn was sung to it. Only one verse of this hymn has been obtained, apparently the first. It dfers in dferent localities: [Early on Bride’s mornThe serpent shall come from the hole, I shall not molest the serpent, Nor will the serpent molest me.’ The snake is a powerful element in mythology and religion and a creature to be respected as the ‘hymn’ makes clear. Familiar in the snake coiled round the rod, it is a symbol of medicine and healing, and the appearance of the adder or snake on Saint Bride’s Day offers a feeling of hope and transformation, and of turning the corner with the ening of the days. . century. .!... !

title: special donnie munro concert to bring skye live back with a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe island#s premier music festival is set toin style on Thursday th May # following a two-year break due to the pandemic # with an opening night extravaganza # ‘Coming Home: An Evening with Donnie Munro and friends’ and featuring special guests in the form of multi-award-winning Gaelic supergroup Mànran.The show will be Donnie’s first in his hometown since  and will see him perform with a full eight-piece band line-up on the spectacular Skye Live Festival site at Am Meall in Portree. The singer said: #This offers me a fantastic opportunity to bring this amazing line-up, featuring some of Scotland’s top musicians together, for an exclusive performance to open this year’s Skye Live Festival.He added: #It has been fantastic to watch the festival grow in strength, year on year, in what must be one of the most special and unique festival locations anywhere in the world, and to see it become internationally recognised as, ‘one of the best boutique festivals in the country’, is just fantastic for the island, and it is such a great honour for me to be invited to be a part of it all and to be bringing the music back home here to where it all began.#Joining Donnie Munro on the night will be Mànran, internationally recognised as one of the most iconic and respected Scottish bands on the road today. With three hugely successful studio albums under their belt, in October  the band released their fourth, titled ÙRAR to critical acclaim, and adding to their success, lead female vocalist, Kim Carnie was crowned ‘Gaelic Singer of the Year’ at the  Hands up for Trad Awards.Mànran founder and accordionist Gary Innes said: #Playing on the Isle of Skye has always been a special night for Mànran over the years but joining Donnie and his band as their special guests for Skye Live will certainly be a night to remember.#.

title: ballymena runners support air ambulance
story: THANKS to the generosity of runners and spectators at Race Over the Glens on New Years Day, committee memberAidy Dodds was able to present a cheque for pound to Air Ambulance NI.The charity Air Ambulance Northern Ireland, in partnership with the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service, provides the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service for Northern Ireland. The service brings urgent medical assistance to anywhere in the province, operating seven days a week for  hours per day. It can get to anywhere in Northern Ireland in approximately twenty-five minutes.From inception to August  the medical crew have been tasked , times.The service was called out on  occasions from January – March , an increase of  % on the previous year and a % increase from .The HEMS team attend patients who are seriously ill or injured, bringing emergency pre-hospital care direct to the casualty with the aim of saving lives, brains, and limbs.Air Ambulance NI needs to raise poundmillion each year to maintain this service so public donations are crucial. Fundraising has been severely impacted by Covid, so Ballymena Runners are delighted to be able to play a small part in supporting this worthy cause.

title: gala night and charity auction to raise funds for air ambulance ni in memory of naomi lynn
story: A Gala Dinner and Charity Auction in memory of Naomi Lynn, who tragically lost her le alongside her friend Andrew Burke in , will be held at the Tullyglass House Hotel on Saturday, February ,  at .pm.After a long year and ious hurdles along the way due to the Coronavirus pandemic, the Gala Dinner and Charity Auction organised in memory of the very popular young woman is finally going ahead.Naomi and Andrew, both in their early s, were involved in a fatal road traffic accident near Glarryford on February , ,Tributes and condolences poured in from many friends, colleagues, and family members mourning the tragic loss of the two young friends.Naomis parents, Bryan and Barbara, decided to organise a Gala Night in order to raise funds for Air Ambulance NI, as well as to raise awareness of the critical services the Air Ambulance provides.The event, originally planned for last year was postponed due to Covid- restrictions, however, with these measures now easing, the event is scheduled to take place on February .Naomis father Bryan Lynn told the Ballymena : “Just knowing that this amazing charity was on the scene so quickly and did everything they could for Naomi and her friend Andrew has been such a comfort to us.And knowing the fantastic work they continue to do for other families like ours means we know how important it is to support this truly amazing cause.Since the event was first postponed, there have been many times that the family have questionedand when the event should go ahead.Remembering Naomi and her friend, and supporting the Air Ambulance is so important to the family. But at the same time, Covid has had a huge impact, as many well know.With the recent easing of restrictions, the time now feels right for the event to go ahead.And it’s shaping up to be a really special night with prosecco and renowned harpist Les Magee playing on arrival, a fabulous four course gala meal, a fantastic charity auction and raffle with some really fantastic prizes, music by the Coves and DJ to follow.“We would love to see as many people there as possible. Friends and family of Naomi or just anyone who would like to have a night to remember in support of this amazing cause.Tickets are pound and are still available from Milanos, Ballymena.A spokesperson from Air Ambulance NI said:“We are very grateful to Bryan and the family for organising this evening in memory of Naomi.We all wish that the outcome could have been dferent.The funds raised will give hope to another patient and family in the worst situation and provide an opportunity for the family and local community to honour Naomi’s memory.”

Picture date: Thursday, November , .PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCiaran Hinds attends the Irish premiere of film Belfast at the Waterfront Hall, to mark the opening night of the Belfast Film Festival. Picture date: Thursday, November , .Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailWith Sir Kenneth Branagh’s Belfast receiving seven Oscar nominations, it’s doubtful the film will win a clean sweep. However, local industry experts are hoping Belfast-born Ciaran Hinds takes home his nod for Best Actor in a Supporting Role.“We would all like to see Ciaran Hinds get something, not just for the film, but because he#s such a decent bloke and a brilliant actor,” said Hugh Odling-Smee, a writer and theatre producer from Belfast. Hindsplays Pop in Branagh’s semi-autobiographical movie.Read MoreEimear McGovern:OpinionProud to be sweet: Film’s spectacular success built on unapologetic nostalgiaKenneth Branagh hails his home city as Belfast gets Oscar nods and he makes film historyMr Odling-Smee is also the project manager for Film Hub NI and added that “anybody who knows Ciaran will know exactly what he’s like, he’s always been very supportive of young actors”.This glowing praise was backed up in a tweet on Monday when writer Michael Patrick told the story of how Hinds refused to let the Irish drama society at Cambridge University pay for his travel or accommodation when he was invited to give a talk.“Ciaran Hinds: Oscar Nominee. I organised a talk he gave at my Uni when I was there. He refused to let us pay for his travel or book him into a nice hotel,” posted the creator of BBC Three comedy, My Left Nut.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He said that the star of HBO’s acclaimed TV series Rome had instead said: “Just get me a spare room in your halls of residence, that#ll do me.”“He was honestly the kindest and nicest man to everyone there,” Patrick added.“Bumped into him a few times since and he#s always remembered me, gave me a bit of advice after leaving drama school and all - couldn#t say anything better about him. And he#s an absolutely phenomenal actor.”Ciarán Hinds: Oscar Nominee.I organized a talk he gave at my Uni when I was there. He refused to let us pay for his travel or book him into a nice hotel."Just get me a spare room in your halls of residence, that#ll do me"Star of HBO#s Rome just chilling in our halls.— Michael PatrickFebruary , Mr Odling-Smee believes Belfast is up against some stf competition in its other categories. He feels The Power of the Dog’s Jane Campion could pip Branagh for Best Director and that Kirsten Dunst could edge out Judi Dench as Best Supporting Actress.However, he says Belfast is a strong frontrunner for Best Picture, and even though the bookies have it second to The Power of the Dog for that prize, acknowledged that “the Oscars can be full of surprises”.“A film can just land at exactly the right time, and I think Belfast is one of them. I think that we’ve all been through so much over the last two or three years,” he said.“This is a genuine escapist film in the sense that you’re skipping into another world in the past, obviously, but it’s recognisable for people as well. It’s a fairly straightforward story of a family who find themselves in a very dficult situation and have to make a big choice about where they live and who they are.“I think that#s what people engage with. Belfast is important as a backdrop, but I think it’s that sense of escapism. The film is shot with a sense of escape - going to the cinema, in a dark place with a lot of other people - Belfast has recaptured that sense of going to see a film in the proper way. There are lots of bits where Buddy [played by Jude Hill] and his family go to see films. It was a black and white world but when they went to the cinema, it was in colour.”Mr Odling-Smee also believes that while some critics have accused the movie of not delving into the details of the Troubles in the same way it does the setting of the film, this is the probable reason for its huge popularity.He added: “I think what people miss to a certain extent is that it’s from a child’s view of what is happening. Buddy is trying to work out the world he’s going into. If we all remember back to the Troubles, we didn#t necessarily understand all the things that were happening around us when we were aged  or .“We understood the basics, we understood that maybe there were two tribes, but we didn#t understand all the nuances and the roots of it. As adults, we barely understand it. The accused is further alleged to have assaulted two people and allegedly made a threat to damage windows at an address at Drummond Court.The charges relate to October , . The defendant has been in custody since October after being unable to make bail.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up She appeared at court via a video link from prison.A defence lawyer said the case allegedly involved “waving an imitation firearm at a neighbour in a street and then there is a small amount of cannabis growing in her house”.That case was adjourned to February .Regarding the defendant’s dog and  fish the defence lawyer said a Council had made an application for a “Disposal Order”.He said the defendant “does not consent” to the Order.District Judge Nigel Broderick asked who was looking after the dog and  fish while the defendant is in custody and the defence lawyer said: “I believe it is the Council”.A legal representative for a local Council told the court to date it had cost around £, to look after the animals — £ for the dog and £ for the fish per day.The judge asked: “What sort of fish are we talking about ”The Council lawyer said she was not sure.Judge Broderick said: “I hope it is not goldfish”.The Council lawyer said the fish were in a “filtered tank” and added: “I don’t think they’re goldfish.”The judge added: “It costs £ a day to look after  fish in a tank of water. I find that very hard to understand”.The judge said it was a “struggle” for him to understand the cost, adding: “The dog yes but the fish, really  It seems exorbitant to me but that is just my preliminary view.”The judge wanted to know on what basis the council was making the application and askedthere had been a conviction regarding the animals.The council lawyer said: “No, there hasn’t been a conviction or a decision on prosecution in the matter yet. The Council were contacted by police on the date of Ms Martin’s arrest and advised that animals were in the property.“Once they had ensured that the property was not being accessed by anyone  and the animals not being looked after the animals were therefore seized.“Given that Ms Martin has remained in custody since October we haven’t had any approach from anyone willing to assist in the care of the animals so the Council has had to remain their custodian.”The court heard the dispute about the application will have to be fixed for a hearing.The council lawyer said a council officer and a vet title: lisburn blaze at ashvale farm shop blow to the community
story: The fire took place at Ashvale Farm Shop on the Old Ballynahinch Road in Lisburn. Pic Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker.William Herron from Ashvale Farm Shop. Pic Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker.The fire took place at Ashvale Farm Shop on the Old Ballynahinch Road in Lisburn. Pic Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe fire took place at Ashvale Farm Shop on the Old Ballynahinch Road in Lisburn. Pic Colm Lenaghan Pacemaker.Ralph HewittTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA blaze at the Ashvale Farm Shop in Lisburn has been described as a “blow to the community”, as local SDLP MLA Pat Catney urged people to rally around the Herron family, who own the shop.The Northern Ireland Fire and Rescue Serviceis still understood to be dealing with the fire.Firefighters were called to the incident at the premises on the Old Ballynahinch Road at .am on Wednesday.Forty-five firefighters were in attendance at the fire’s height, as well as six appliances - two from Lisburn, two from Belfast, one from Ballynahinch and one from Carryduff - an aerial ladder appliance from Belfast, a water tanker from Warrenpoint and a command unit from Kilrea.The NIFRS said firefighting operations are ongoing at a reduced scale and all persons were accounted for.Firefighters worked in dficult conditions to stop the blaze spreading to an adjoining shop.The cause of the inferno is undetermined at this time.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseThe fire took place at Ashvale Farm Shop on the Old Ballynahinch Road in Lisburn. Pic: Pacemaker. Pic Colm Lenaghan  Pacemaker FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe fire took place at Ashvale Farm Shop on the Old Ballynahinch Road in Lisburn. Pic: Pacemaker. Pic Colm Lenaghan  PacemakerSDLP Lagan Valley MLA Pat Catney said the fire was a “blow to the entire community”.“Ashvale Farm Shop is a huge part of the local community here in Lisburn and I know that everyone in this area will be hoping the damage caused by the fire is not too severe and they will soon be able to reopen their doors,” he said.“My thoughts are with the Herron family and all the staff today, I know how much pride they take in their business and their work. I’d also like to pay tribute to the work of the firefighters involved in tackling this blaze.They put themselves in harm’s way and have done everything they can to minimise the damage and stop the fire spreading. I#m glad nobody was hurt or caught up in this fire.“I will be making contact with the Herron family soon to seethere’s anything that can be done to provide them with assistance and I’d urge the community to rally around them and give all the support they can at this trying time.”NIFRS group commander Suzanne Fleming, said on Tuesday morning: “NIFRS are attending a well-developed fire in a storeroom on Old Ballynahinch Road, Lisburn.“Firefighting conditions were challenging on arrival, and firefighting operations include crews wearing breathing apparatus, and ious water jets are in use to prevent fire spread.”A spokesperson for the PSNI said: “Police were made aware of a fire at commercial premises at Old Ballynahinch Road, Lisburn, shortly after .am today, Wednesday. Officers attended, however there was no requirement for any road closures or further police involvement.”Most Read‘Keep calm and carry on as Northern Ireland Protocol is here to stay’… investment
